Schools offer these to make themselves sound more competitive, when, in reality, these mean nothing. It depends on what types of jobs you'll be looking for post graduation. If your going Biglaw, they won't care what your certificate is in. But, if you go in-house/JD Advantage or small firm, then they may take your certificate as a plus because you've "concentrated" in a specific area of the law.
All these things are is a way for a school to forecast what classes they need to offer. If you have 10 students going through X certificate path, then they know your going to have 10 students that need the required classes A,B,C, and D.

If you need any other help I can work through the UCC (A2;A3;A4;A9; and the Bankruptcy Code) pretty easily.
Just hit me up.

* 9-109(A/1): Remember A9 does not apply to security interests (SI) in real property, this section creates an exception that, "AP applies to any transaction that creates a SI in personal or *fixtures*..."
* 9-102(A/41): Under the UCC there is a limited definition for Fixtures, which means "goods that have become so related to a particular real property that an interest in them arises under Real Property Law." This is quite vauge, and being that there are 50 states, all with different real property law--this definition does not help much.
* George vs. Commerical Credit Corp. Case: The court in George identified a 3-part test to determine whether a good was a fixture. In order to be a fixture, the good must satisfy ALL 3 prongs, (1) Whether or not the good has been physically annexed to the property; (2) Whether or not it has adapted to the use or the purpose for which the real property is devoted to; and (3) The *INTENT* of the person was to make a permanent accession to the freehold.
* Analysis the 3 prongs above
* 9-501(A/1/B): Remembering that traditionally to protect a SI the secured creditor files a financing statement at the secretary of state in which the Debtor is located. Fixtures are different, they must be filed at the County Registrar of Deeds in order to be effective, this is called a fixture filing.
* 9-502(B)/Lewiston Case: Provides for the requirements for a Fixture filing-most important is the name or the property owner and not of the Debtor; these can be different if the Debtor is leasing. If the name is not of the property owner then the filing is ineffective.
* 9-501(b): This is known as the *Transmitting Utilities Exception*, which has the effect to allow the Creditor to go back to the general rule for Finance Statements and file at the secretary of state which covers the entire state.
* 9-334: Governs the Priority Rules regarding fixtures. The main battle the UCC is worried about involved the Creditor who has a SI in a fixture and has filed a fixture filing vs. someone (creditor/owner) who has a SI in the fixtures by virture of having a mortgage interest in the real property the fixture is located.
* 9-334(c): Established the general rule that a SI in fixtures is subordinate to a conflicting SI of a mortgagee, or the owner of the real property, other than the Debtor. Where an individual is leasing the property to which a fixture sits, the SI will be senior to that interest.
* Exception to the general rule: One big exception to this general rule is that where there are conflicting SI of an encumbrance/mortgage, if the Debtor has an interest of record in the real property, or is in the possession of the real property. An interest of record simply means they have recorded their interest in the real property and have perfected through a fixture filing before the encumbrance's interest was recorded. This is the basic race rule, whoever has done things first has won the basic priority battle.
* 9-334(d): Exception to the general priority rule above, this is the PMSI Fixture Super Priority Exception.
* 9-334(h): Exception to the general priority rule above, this is the Construction Mortgage Super Super Priority Exception.
* 9-334(e/2): Exception to the general rule that a fixture may not be removed once its situated, if its readily removable.
* 9-604(d): Damages reimbursement; A secured creditor shall promptly reimburse any encumbrancer/mortgagee/ owner of the real property for the cost of repair of any physical damages caused by the removal of the fixture. Before the removal, assurances of payment/bond may be sought to protect the real property.
* 9-334(e/3): Gives the rule where a Judicial Lien Creditor obtains a lien on the fixture property. After the secured creditor has perfected in the fixture by filing a fixture filing; under the general rule in 9-317(a) the secured creditor has perfected before the judicial lien attached, and therefore has priority over a judicial lien creditor.

Money Damages are the typical remedy in Contract/Sales Law. The overall goal: *Is to put the non-breaching party in as good a position as performance would have done, plus consequential and incidental damages, if any, less possible mitigation of damages.*
The two main ways to calculate money damages are: (1) Expectation Damages; (2) Reliance Damages.
**Expectation Damages** are intended to put the injured party in the same position as if the contract had been fully performed.
There are three major limits on calculating Expectation Damages:
* (1) Expectation Damages MUST be proven with reasonable certainty given the P's position; Brand new or unproven business ventures have issues proving lost profits from lack of a consistent sales record.
* (2) Consequential Damages are NOT recoverable unless the damages were reasonably foreseeable and contemplated at the time of the contracts formation (Hadley Rule)
* (3) Once a breach has occurred both parties must take reasonable steps to mitigate damages resulting from the breach.
**Reliance Damages** are intended to put the party in the same economic position they would be had the contract never been formed in the first place.
Reliance damages may be recovered if a non-breaching party incurs expenses in reasonable reliance upon the promise that the other party would perform; these are the steps the parties have taken towards performance of the contract.
**A PARTY CANNOT RECOVER BOTH** Expectation and Reliance Damages--so you must choose what damages to seek.
**Detrimental Reliance** is not a form of damages. Generally an Offeror is free to revoke any offer anytime before the Offeree accepts. However, the Offeror's power to revoke their offer is restricted under Detrimental Reliance because the Offeree has reasonably and detrimentally relied on the offer in a foreseeable manner.
Damages are very fact specific. I don't remember a case with Det. Reli. in it dealing with damages. I guess you could for see a case where someone has tried/revoked their offer, but the offer was accepted and the offeree had incurred damages as a result of the offeror's revocation/their partial performance.

Well that's a skewed example. To be a physics teacher at a college level will be different then at a high school or middle school level.
The necessary steps are the boxes you need to know and check in order to reach your goals. If you don't know what you need to do, then that's step one.
Figure out everything you can about what you want to achieve and in the process you will know the direction you must travel. There is nothing simple about starting from the bottom. You have nothing but a goal, you've made strides towards your goal, but this is only the beginning--gain as much experience as you can and use everything you've learned to your advantage.
When you've taken all the necessary steps and your ready to take the first leap!

Hmm, well technically you can enter into a legal contract on your own behalf. The contract would be *voidable*, but not void itself.
Regardless, rough circumstances, good job being smart and mature about everything...seriously.
Let's start with the bank account. If your parents are on it your going to need their permission to close it, take their names off, or do anything significant with it.
To play into your cash option, which isn't bad, you could slowly start taking money out and saving it as cash. BUT, your going to want to really safeguard that cash. You should get a waterproof/fire resistant lockbox and store the cash in there.
You could also check with the bank and ask if they could set you up with a bank savings account without a co-signer. Usually the co-signers are on checking accounts for security purposes if the primary individual bounces/overdrafts on the checking account. You obviously can't do that with a savings account.
I think those would be your best options moving forward.

With that I would also question brand.
For example, Chevrolet has a 10yr/100,000 mi powertrain warranty that is transferable; even if you buy it used with no warranty and "as is where is" from the Seller, it's a Manufacturers warranty.
So, 2005 is out of warranty and 2015 is within warranty still.
It really depends on many variables.

It's a slippery slope.
You could take it, use it, and then they could bad mouth you behind your back or say you couldn't perform at that level. Two to three months isn't even 90 days which is the usual let go for under performing period.
If your considering taking it I would suggest staying with the company for at least 6months if not 1 year. This will allow you to establish your position and show that you gained true experience; 2-3 months isn't even enough time to really engulf yourself with what your doing.
Your boss is an asshat. Plain and simple. Just keep it to yourself and know their true character. Take the salary bump and perks that come along with it and use the opportunity to your advantage to take that next rung in life when it comes.

(They go this all the time).

No, incorrect.
*Very basic overview*: You need to qualify and then make 120 qualifying payments for 10 years. To qualify you must work for a govt. full time or a non-profit.
(12 payments per year for 10 years)
It's only for amounts you currently have outstanding. But the clock will start running as soon as the fund are dispersed to you. Regardless you more than likely (99.99%) qualify now and haven't even taken advantage of it. I read a study that more than 83% of outstanding FEDERAL student loan holders qualify and they are not taking advantage of the PSLF program.
I would look into it ASAP for the loans you have out now. Go check out the [PSLF WEBSITE](https://studentaid.ed.gov/sa/repay-loans/forgiveness-cancellation/public-service).
